Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: IDBR Type A: QSTORM-AO - Wavefront-shaping light-sheet microscopy with photoswitchable quantum dots for superresolution imaging in thick tissue
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Georgia to develop a novel super-resolution microscope for biological research. For students and early-career researchers, this close collaboration at the intersection of biology, physics, optics, and chemical engineering will provide an invaluable training experience, and it will be enriched with professional development in interdisciplinary science communication skills. All team members will contribute to the development of an online team blog, lab notebook, and public website that will capture the progress of the research within a broader historical, scientific, and visual context, curated by the Boston Museum of Science. The Museum of Science team will also disseminate this work to thousands of science museum visitors, students, and the broader community with live presentations, demonstrations, podcasts, and a short NOVA-style film on the quest to see more clearly and deeply into the mysteries of life. The film will be directed by a multiple award-winning NOVA producer.

This instrument will combine holographic imaging using high resolution spatial light modulators and new techniques for correcting distortion induced by light scattering in thick biological tissue to achieve molecular-scale resolution inside organisms important for modern biological research, such as fruit flies and zebrafish. At The Ohio State University, semiconductor nanotechnology will be combined with DNA origami to create intensely bright and switchable light emitters, individually targetable to selected molecules operating within biological systems. This novel combination of high-precision technologies will provide investigators an unprecedented view of important subcellular biological processes, such as neuronal signaling in intact organisms, potentially contributing to breakthroughs in areas of molecular and systems biology, biological engineering, medicine, and human health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this award, we have developed techniques for improving the performance of single molecule localization microscopy in thick tissue. Single molecule localization microscopy (SMLM) is a fluorescence microscopy technique that can achieve resolutions down to 10 nanometers allowing precise imaging of structures and interactions within single cells. In contrast, conventional fluorescence microscopy techniques have a resolution limit of about 250 nm and cannot resolve many complex structures within the cell. This technique suffers from two difficulties. First when imaging into thicker samples, optical aberrations, scattering and background severely degrade the ability of this technique in samples larger than a single cell. Secondly, the main variations of this technique can only provide volumetric imaging over a volume with axial dimension of about one micron. Therefore, SMLM cannot image even a single cell without mechanically refocusing.

Continuing work funded by a previous NSF award, we have developed approaches for correcting optical aberrations as SMLM data is being collected. These methods are based on machine learning optimization techniques that are well-suited to working with the stochastic nature of raw SMLM data. We have demonstrated wavefront correction imaging through the nucleus of a cell and into the central nervous system of a fruit fly larva.

We are developing a novel incoherent holographic technique for single-molecule imaging over a large axial range without mechanical movement. We have demonstrated holographic imaging and localization of fluorescent microspheres emitting a few tens of thousands of photons. We are able to image over a 20 micron axial range with 5 nm lateral and 40 nm axial precision. To further enhance our imaging sensitivity, we have built a light-sheet illumination system for our single-molecule localization microscope which minimizes background noise. We have further done a theoretical analysis to demonstrate the potential of holographic imaging for high precision localization over an extended axial range.

This grant has also supported collaborative work on single molecule microscopy at the University of Georgia. We have collaborated with the lab of Dr. Rabin De La Fuente to image the synaptonemal complex in chromosomal spreads and we are currently contributing to the study of synaptogenesis in fruit flies, collaborating with the lab of Dr. Daichi Kamiyama.

This grant has contributed to the training of two graduate students. One student is currently a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Georgia and the other student will graduate this year and start a postdoctoral position at the Georgia Institute of Technology. Four undergraduates have contributed to this project. Two of these students are now in graduate school. As part of this project, we have contributed to the QSTORM website maintained by our collaborator, Carol Lynn Alpert at the Museum of Science. This website documents our research and provides visitors insight into the challenges of the research process.
